The appellant file a demur to this information on two grounds.

One was that its terms are vague and uncertain in meaning, thereby depriving here of due process; The second ground for demur was that the statute discriminates against certain females; that is unmarried females between the ages of 18 and 21 without basis for its support and thereby denying equal protection.
On the same day, the demur was filed, the State of Connecticut filed a substitute information alleging two additional charges.

One was violation of Section 53-219 of the general statutes that statute entitled “lascivious carriage and fornication”, and Section 53-175 of the statutes which is the disorderly conduct statute, the demur was overruled, the plaintiff pleaded not guilty to all charges elected a trial to the Court was found guilty of 17-379, guilty of 53-219, and not guilty of disorderly conduct.
And her sentence was commitment to the study -- the Connecticut State Farm for Women.
I think all parties agree that these sentences were concurrent under applicable Connecticut law.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But you say not --

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: On 53 -- excuse me.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if I understand you now what you have been saying is that there's never been an appeal from the conviction for lascivious carriage which carried with it the three-year sentence, if it's properly called a sentence.
That's what you're saying, isn't it?
And therefore, there can't be any issue as to that sentence before this Court since it had never been brought before any Connecticut Appellate Court, is that it?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
It should've been brought by appeal or by habeas corpus if they want to attack that sentence, but the sentence standards, there's maximum of three years.
There's no change in that sentence.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Carroll.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: On the statute that she was convicted on and I understand from your brief at page 13, am I correct that you take the position that vise and habits of vise are no more or no less on ambiguous in the word “obscene”, is that position you take?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: I think that there are at least, that the word “vise” is at least this clear in common language --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But no more so than obscene?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: That's a hard thing to answer Mr. Justice as a matter of degree.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I just want to --

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: I think vise is prefers more clear.

And if I may just to expound from that, a federal case which didn't involved with criminal conviction but did say about vise that nothing is -- well, I'll paraphrase it, nothing is more clear that promiscuous and uninhibited sexual intercourse is vise that that's -- if anything is vise, that's it.

And you see here unfortunately, we don't have the facts before the Court to or the record of the conduct of this young woman to measure against the words of the statute because I think this is a type of statute that in certain cases could be applied in nonconstitutional manner.
It is not unconstitutionally void for vagueness on its face but that the Court should have the benefit of the conduct to measure against the words of the statute.

And after all, isn't that only logical because the reasons for the statute being void for vagueness and therefore denial of due process are to, primarily that the actor doesn't know what conduct is proscribed.

Well, I say that the record of this case would reveal that this actor or any actor would know that the conduct would come within the purview of the word “vise”, but not having that before it is another reason.
The state maintains that the Court should not disturb --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There's been proper in this situation to bring the record here?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: It wasn't made a part of the record.
You mean the transcript Your Honor of the evidence?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, would've there been proper for counsel to put that in the appendix?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: The Court --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- or not under the appellate procedure?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Are not the way the appeal was taken, no because it was just an appeal from the overruling of the demur.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, that you don't question whether it should've been here or not?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, well, yes I do because under our practice in the case that I've cited in my brief called State versus Sol is that you cannot -- the overrule by a demur to the constitutionality of the statute then proceed to a full trial and be convicted and then appeal the overruling of the demur without any evidence before the Appellate Court.
That's our law under the case of State versus Sol.
I should add as I did in the brief however that the Court said but anyhow, we're going to look at the situation because of the constitutional issues that were involved.

But they clearly set forth in the Connecticut law and namely there shouldn't be here or shouldn't be in the Connecticut Appellate Court in this form because the demur, having been overruled, then the trial, and then the conviction Mr. defense counsel made a motion dismiss that on the appeal, the record of that trial should be before the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The overruling of the demur or the -- comes to conviction?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: The overruling the demur.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And what you said that is the practice if you appeal with the overruling of the demur but there been a substantive trial after the overruling the demur that the Appellate Court must have the trial before it?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what I'm interested in, do you question whether the appeal is properly before us in this posture?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I do because --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you argue that in your brief?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I don't know if I argue just in the terms that Chief Justice means but I argue with in terms of the state -- this Court being unable to pass upon the statute without having before it the facts that were brought out at the trial and were the basis of her conviction under it.
I haven't --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's the additional independent state ground isn't it?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, it is but I think Mr. Chief Justice's point that I have made a procedural argument on that.
I made -- I've tried to make a substantive argument of it in terms of where's the Court should consider not having the record before it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but you said the Court of Appeals I gather that -- Connecticut nevertheless -- the statute?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: It did involve --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- involve or was not part as a practice of argument.
The trial record before gone the appeal the overruling of the demur, is that right?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, and that -- the leading --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But why would he not, when he able also to do what your advice of?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: I'm sorry, I'd certainly wouldn't deny you that prerogative -- I would say though, and that's why I think I cast this more in terms the practical difficulty of applying a statute to a set of facts that are non-existing.
I think Justice Frankfurter said one case is like playing hammer without hammer.

And I think that's what we have here and I think their statutes are come under free speech restrictions that this Court can look at it and has looked at and said these are patently and on their face unconstitutionally void for vagueness.
But I don't think this is that kind of statute.

It's talking about conduct which is not within the constitutionally protected area and I think in that type of case and the cases that I cited in my brief on this point that the Court should have the facts before it, and if it doesn't that's fatal.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: May I ask you for a quick moment.
May I ask you of the question try to clarify the underlying sentence situation in my mind?
If a woman age 22 were arrested and convicted of the crime of lascivious carriage under your statute, what would be her sentence?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Six months maximum.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, what happen here is that this moment being under 21, 16 or 17 was convicted of that same crime of lascivious carriage, and your position is that the effective sentence was three years because of the order committing her to the State Farm for women, is that right?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But so far as the conviction of the crime of lascivious carriage is concern, the sentence provided by Section 53 whenever it is, is six months, is that right?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And the three-year hypothesis depends solely upon what is it, Section 17-360?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And Section 17-360 makes no reference to the crime of lascivious carriage, but provides only as I understand it that the maximum commitment to the State Farm for Women shall be three years, is that right?
Are you relying on the provision in 17-360 that says that the maximum commitment to the State Farm for women shall be three years?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: I'm relying on 17-360 but the different part of it.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Please tell me what part of it.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Persons who maybe committed to this institution, persons who plead guilty to the commission of felonies which this is not, second persons convicted of or who plead guilty to the commission of misdemeanors including prostitution, intoxication, drug using and disorderly conduct.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But not lascivious carriage?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: No, but that's -- I will take that to mean including, but not eliminating or not being exclusive.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: You mean the listing is not exclusive?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: All right, go ahead.
I'm sorry.
Read -- I mean say read the rest of that will you please?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

The commission of misdemeanor including the prostitution, intoxication, drug using and disorderly conduct, and third unmarried girls between the ages 16 and 21 or manifest danger falling into habits of vise which was the other -- which was the commitment provision for the conviction under Section 17-379.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, all right now, tell me in summary if you don't mind just how -- just on what theory keeping those statutory sections in mind you contend that appellant here is serving a three-year sentence as a result of her conviction of the crime of lascivious carriage?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

If I may just take Section 17-379 which was the actual conviction for manifest danger falling to habits of vise, 17-379 says, “Any unmarried female between the ages of 16 and 21 who is in manifest danger of falling to habits of vise or leading the vicious life or who has committed any crime upon the complaint maybe brought before the Court and committed.
And then it goes on to say in effect that she maybe committed to the Connecticut State Farm for Women until she's 21.
In this Section, it doesn't mentioned the Connecticut State Farm for Women, but there's no question that that's what it's talking about, the institution that it's talking about.
So, she's convicted of 17-379 -- she's convicted of manifest danger under 17-379.
Under 53-219, she's convicted of lascivious carriage.
And either the words in 17-379 or who has committed any crime or the words that I read before in 17-360, the commission of misdemeanors including prostitution, etcetera, are applicable.

And she has committed under the maximum three-year sentence in 17-360 for the crime of lascivious carriage as well as for the manifest danger falling into vise charge under the two statutes, 53-219 and 17-379.
17-360 says she has to stay there for a maximum of three years including parole.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: 17-360 says she has to stay there for three years?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Well, no.
I should say she just exposed to being there for three years.
That's the maximum sentence since three years is the maximum sentence.

And there's confusion in 17-379 which says 21 but as we said earlier I don't think there's any question that as to this young lady, 17-360 three-year maximum is applicable because it would be longer than that to make to have her attain 21 and the lesser is applicable.
So, under 17-360, she has a maximum exposure of three years on both the charges of which she was convicted.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: This is an extraordinary Chinese puzzle isn't it?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is the charge?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: It's a little -- pardon me Your Honor?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is the charge granted in the record indictment or the information or whatever it is?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: There's an information in the substitute information in the record and the information that's applicable is on page -- well, its right after page 4 and it's called the substitute information.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, do you read this as making it the crime for girl to be at manifest danger or contract to the habits of vise?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: That's what falling into habits of vise, yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, how do you prove that by the environment or context?
The fact that she's living in the city where there are lot of temptation or how could it be proved, that's all?
That's just the possibility of what mayhem somebody in the future.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: It's a danger, yes.
It's -- the word “danger” --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: She contain, you convict her being in danger?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you have a course of conduct?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: There's a course of conduct and if the conduct were before the Court, it would be clear that there's more than a danger.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But would it be clear that's not what the statute say.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: No.
That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Manifest danger?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has the Court ever construed it of being a crime to be in manifest danger to your Supreme Court?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has it ever construed it at all?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there have been in the case to sustain?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: I -- I don't think there's been a case that's all applicable, no.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it's the only case it's ever been in state since its Title of 95?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, no.
There have been convictions on this, but there's no appellate decision on the statute as far as I know that has any bearing on the problem before us now.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How do you know there's been a conviction?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: I know there's been a convictions because I have been prosecuting for long time and I know that other prosecutors in fact in their brief, they -- the appellant sets forth the use of the statute by prosecutors in the State of Connecticut.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But this is not for conduct, this is of being in danger.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm saying Your Honor that the case that I'm referring to are all for conduct, although I have to agree with you.
The statute says danger of falling into habits --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's the charge here.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And we have to consider it on the basis of whether that's a good statute can do on it.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I wouldn't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And convict somebody of a crime -- do you call it a crime to be in danger?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: I wouldn't defend the statute at all, Your Honor, if I didn't believe that to mean a criminal.
A criminal -- the criminal conduct had to be invalid, and I think the other words of that statute --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Criminal is a crime then you placed somewhere where you are in danger, do you kept it to do something wrong?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I suppose there are degrees of vise Your Honor.
I don't think the statute should be or could be properly applied unless the danger had been realized.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But they don't fix in the punishment like penalty or fine or imprisonment, they just put them in jail like put a child -- the parent will put it in the back room.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, well, there's a maximum --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- or finally take care and see that she'd not have any danger -- being in a danger there after.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I don't think we can avoid the penal nature of this.
That's the idea, to rehabilitate it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I know.
It seems to me like it's not a crime they way they handle that part, put her in jail just to take care of that and get out of danger.
Of course, you might not be completely out of danger to that.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Well, she's out of there now anyhow, but the fact --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And why do we have to pass on it is she's out of the --

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Well, their point is that she's on parole and the parole continues until --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you agree that she's on parole?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, she's on parole I think it --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Then, it's not a moot of course.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: I don't claim it's moot, no, but I claim --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you do claim she's on parole on a concurrent sentence which has not in no way been attack.

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: -- I don't think that's technically mootness, but we certainly raise that argument very strongly.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, we have before us as I understand the two problems.
Let's see if I get this correct.

First, is this Chinese puzzle of that -- of extrapolating the six months sentence for lascivious carriage in to a three months commitment to the State Farm for women, if its three months and we regard that as a sentence and you get an exact identity with the length of the sentence under the danger resulting from being a female statute.
And if that is so, then we have the problem of concurrent sentences because of lascivious carriage conviction is not before us.

Then, if we can consider the raise up solacritor criminal statute, the danger of being a woman in Newhaven of Connecticut, then I suppose that -- then we get into the questions that Mr. Justice Black was raising.
Is that a correct analysis of it?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct analysis but I don't think that the sentencing provisions are really not much of the Chinese puzzle.
Maybe I'm going more by practice than by what's spelled out.
But I think but I think if you read 379 and 360 and 53-219 that there's no question that she is properly sent there for three years under 53-219.
And these decisions mentioned by counsel, I don't believe that fact in this case.
And I just -- if I may add a word on the vise.

When we're talking about vise, I think it's clear from the context of the statute; the other language in the statute that it's criminal vise -- have a vise of smoking cigarettes or all kinds of vises which were used more even incuriously than that of course, but the whole context of this is talking about criminal vise and the type of vise we think of when we think of a vise squad and --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I suppose you have in Connecticut specific criminal statutes and ordinances making illegal that sort of criminal conduct --

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The sort hard core conduct that everybody seems to be agreed here is covered by this is also covered by specific criminal statutes, is it not?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: I think most of the cases that have come up under this would be covered by specific criminal conduct, yes sir.
And I think it's broader because of the fact that this category of young person was regarded as being in need of particular treatment.

Now this, were drinking involved in the case to this type of drinking may not have -- on her part may not have fit a specific criminal crime -- criminal offense in Connecticut, but she was at the time of 16-year-old girl drinking wine while this other business is going on.
That particular conduct which was in the record, I mean the testimony.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What's a juvenile statute -- what's the upper limit on the age for juvenile court proceedings in Connecticut?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: 16 Your Honor, except that between 16 and 18, the adult court can refer them if they think they are amenable to juvenile court jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that -- but would this young woman had been -- would the juvenile court of the naval day excise jurisdiction over this young woman?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Not unless she was referred by the Court that heard this case prior to the Court hearing.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So that court could have refer her and then she could've been taking care of under the juvenile court statute until she was 21?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, that court could have it, but the court had background of reasons why it didn't.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you know whether there have been any convictions to charge with danger of becoming a cigarette smoker?

turn.speaker: george_f_carroll_jr
turn.label: Mr. George F. Carroll, Jr.
